moe_section_title: Certificates of Release to Service, Incomplete Maintenance, Temporary Installations and Technical Records
summary: Describes planning and recording of repair work, handling of ADs and defects (including deferred defects), issue of certificates of release to service (CRS) for aircraft and components, conditions for issuing a CRS when maintenance is incomplete, temporary use of components without appropriate release documentation, storage and retention of maintenance records, and limited/single-use certifying staff authorisations.

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.50(a), (e) & GM1 145.A.50(a) – aircraft CRS and prohibition when flight safety is endangered
findings.requirement_excerpt: A certificate of release to service shall be issued ... after the maintenance ordered has been properly carried out. ... when the organisation is unable to complete all maintenance ordered, it may issue a certificate of release to service within the approved aircraft limitations. ... A CRS shall not be issued in the case of any known non‑compliance which endangers flight safety.
findings.reasoning: The MOE states that before issuing a CRS the issuer must ensure all maintenance has been carried out and recorded, that the aircraft is airworthy to the extent required by the work order, and that a CRS is not issued if it is suspected the aircraft is not airworthy. It also describes handling of deferred defects and states that a CRS is not issued if the combined effect of deferred defects is suspected to endanger flight safety. However, the text does not clearly state that a CRS may be issued when maintenance is incomplete only within approved aircraft limitations and with explicit recording of those limitations, as required by 145.A.50(e) and M.A.801(f). The wording uses “suspected” rather than clearly prohibiting CRS in any known non‑compliance that endangers flight safety.
findings.recommended_fix:
Amend the CRS section to explicitly reflect the regulatory conditions for incomplete maintenance and the prohibition on CRS when flight safety is endangered. For example:

"When all maintenance ordered has been properly carried out and recorded, and the aircraft is airworthy with respect to the work order and applicable maintenance requirements, an aircraft certificate of release to service (CRS) shall be issued.

If the organisation is unable to complete all maintenance ordered, a CRS may only be issued within the approved aircraft limitations. In such cases, the CRS shall clearly state which maintenance could not be completed and shall indicate all applicable airworthiness and operational limitations in accordance with the approved data (e.g. MEL, maintenance programme, ADs, CAME procedures).

A CRS shall not be issued in the case of any known non‑compliance which endangers flight safety, as defined in GM1 145.A.50(a)."

findings.requirement_id: AMC 145.A.50(b) – CRS statement content and reference to approval number and identity
findings.requirement_excerpt: The certificate of release to service should contain the following statement: ‘Certifies that the work specified, except as otherwise specified, was carried out in accordance with Part‑145 and in respect to that work the aircraft/aircraft component is considered ready for release to service’. Reference should also be made to the EASA Part‑145 approval number and the identity of the person who issued the release.
findings.reasoning: The MOE includes a CRS statement essentially identical to the AMC wording and allows an English equivalent. It also requires that the maintenance certificate identification information includes the company name, licence number and HTA endorsement, and that the person uses full signature and internal authorisation number or stamp. However, it does not explicitly require inclusion of the organisation’s EASA Part‑145 approval number on the CRS, as called for by the AMC.
findings.recommended_fix:
Clarify that the CRS must reference the organisation’s EASA Part‑145 approval number. For example, add:

"Each certificate of release to service shall include the organisation’s full name and EASA Part‑145 approval number, together with the identity (full name), signature and internal authorisation number/stamp of the certifying staff."

findings.requirement_id: AMC 145.A.50(b)(3)-(5) – linkage of CRS to maintenance data, date and summary for extensive maintenance
findings.requirement_excerpt: The certificate of release to service should relate to the task specified in the instructions issued by the (S)TC holder ... or in the aircraft maintenance programme... The date such maintenance was carried out should include when the maintenance took place relative to any life or overhaul limitation... When extensive maintenance has been carried out, it is acceptable for the certificate of release to service to summarise the maintenance as long as there is a unique cross‑reference to the work package containing full details.
findings.reasoning: The MOE requires that the CRS includes the date, flight time and reference to manufacturer’s instructions or the aircraft maintenance programme, and allows a summary description with a reference to the job number for extensive maintenance. This aligns broadly with the AMC. However, it does not explicitly address indicating the maintenance date relative to life/overhaul limitations (hours/cycles/landings) where applicable.
findings.recommended_fix:
Refine the CRS content description to explicitly cover life/overhaul limitations. For example:

"The CRS shall record the date and aircraft total time/landings/cycles, as applicable, so that compliance with any life or overhaul limitations can be determined. For extensive maintenance, a summary description and a unique reference to the detailed work package (job number) is sufficient, provided that the work package contains all dimensional and detailed information."

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.50(d) & AMC1/AMC2 145.A.50(d) – component CRS and EASA Form 1 / internal release
findings.requirement_excerpt: A certificate of release to service shall be issued ... after the maintenance that was ordered has been carried out on a component whilst it was off the aircraft. The authorised release certificate ‘EASA Form 1’ constitutes the component certificate of release to service... When an organisation maintains a component for its own use, the EASA Form 1 may not be necessary if the organisation’s internal release procedures in its MOE so provides. ... A component which has been maintained off the aircraft needs the issuance of a certificate of release to service for such maintenance and another certificate of release to service in regard to being installed properly on the aircraft...
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes issuing a maintenance certificate for parts/devices/equipment and mentions EASA Form 1 when a detached part is serviced or removed and handed over to another maintenance organisation. However, the text is truncated and does not clearly state that: (1) EASA Form 1 is the standard component CRS; (2) a separate CRS is required for installation on the aircraft; and (3) when components are maintained for own use, internal release procedures may be used instead of EASA Form 1, with those procedures clearly defined. The internal release concept is implied but not clearly structured against the AMC.
findings.recommended_fix:
Complete and clarify the component CRS section. For example:

"For components maintained off the aircraft:
- When a serviced or removed component is to be transferred outside the organisation (e.g. to another maintenance organisation or operator), an authorised release certificate EASA Form 1 shall be issued as the component certificate of release to service.
- When a component is maintained for use by this organisation only, an internal release procedure may be used instead of EASA Form 1. This internal release shall be documented in the work order/maintenance records and shall clearly identify the component, the work performed, the applicable maintenance data, and the certifying staff.
- A component maintained off the aircraft requires: (a) a CRS (EASA Form 1 or internal release) for the off‑aircraft maintenance, and (b) a separate aircraft CRS when the component is installed on the aircraft.

The detailed internal release procedure for own‑use components is described in section [x.x.x] of this MOE."

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.50(f) – temporary fitment of components without appropriate release certificate (30 flight hours)
findings.requirement_excerpt: When an aircraft is grounded ... due to the non‑availability of a component with the appropriate release certificate, the organisation ... may temporarily fit a component without the appropriate release certificate for a maximum of 30 flight hours or until the aircraft first returns to the main line station or main maintenance base ... subject to the agreement of the person or organisation responsible for the aircraft’s continuing airworthiness and subject to that component having a suitable release certificate but otherwise in compliance with all applicable maintenance and operational requirements.
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes a "temporary maintenance certificate" situation where an aircraft is left away from the usual maintenance location due to lack of a spare part with an appropriate maintenance certificate. It allows a temporary CRS when a useful spare part without appropriate documentation is installed, with operator’s written consent, and limits use to return to home base or 30 flight hours. This aligns with the 30‑hour limit and operator agreement. However, it does not clearly require that the component has a suitable release certificate (even if not the fully appropriate one) and that all applicable maintenance and operational requirements are otherwise met, as specified in 145.A.50(f). The linkage to 145.A.42 is also not referenced.
findings.recommended_fix:
Refine the temporary installation procedure to mirror 145.A.50(f). For example:

"When an aircraft is grounded away from the main base due to non‑availability of a component with the appropriate release certificate, the organisation may, with the written agreement of the CAMO/CAMO‑equivalent responsible for continuing airworthiness, temporarily install a component without the appropriate release certificate for a maximum of 30 flight hours or until the aircraft first returns to the main line station or main maintenance base, whichever occurs first. The temporarily installed component must:
- have a suitable release certificate or other acceptable evidence of serviceability;
- otherwise comply with all applicable maintenance and operational requirements.

Such temporary installations, including any limitations, shall be recorded in the aircraft technical log and in the maintenance records. The component shall be removed or properly released in accordance with 145.A.42 and 145.A.50 before the time limit is exceeded."

findings.requirement_id: M.A.801(e)(4), (f), (g) & GM1 145.A.50(a) – incomplete maintenance and recording of limitations
findings.requirement_excerpt: When the required maintenance cannot be completed, a CRS may be issued with the approved aircraft limitations. In that case, the certificate shall indicate that the maintenance could not be completed, as well as indicate any applicable airworthiness or operations limitations... A CRS shall not be issued in the case of any known non‑compliance which endangers flight safety.
findings.reasoning: The MOE has a section on "Suspended maintenance maintenance certificate" describing conditions under which a CRS for incomplete maintenance may be issued: operator written approval, MEL/maintenance programme or NAA permission, HTA satisfaction that airworthiness is not endangered, and recording of restrictions and deadlines in the maintenance certificate and monitoring data. This is broadly aligned with the concept of a CRS with limitations. However, the text does not explicitly require that the CRS itself clearly states that maintenance could not be completed and lists all applicable airworthiness/operational limitations, as required by M.A.801(e)(4). The prohibition on CRS in any known non‑compliance that endangers flight safety is only indirectly covered via HTA judgement and "suspected" wording.
findings.recommended_fix:
Strengthen the wording on incomplete maintenance CRS. For example:

"If the maintenance ordered by the operator cannot be completed, the organisation may issue a CRS within the approved aircraft limitations only when:
- the operator provides written approval for the deferral;
- the deferral is in accordance with the MEL, the approved maintenance programme, TC holder data or, where applicable, NAA permission; and
- the certifying staff (HTA) is satisfied that the remaining non‑compliance does not endanger flight safety.

In such cases, the CRS shall explicitly state that the maintenance has not been completed and shall list all applicable airworthiness and operational limitations (including any time or flight limitations). A CRS shall not be issued in the case of any known non‑compliance which endangers flight safety."

findings.requirement_id: GM1 M.A.501(a)(2) – identification and control of unserviceable components
findings.requirement_excerpt: The person or organisation that performs maintenance should ensure the proper identification of any unserviceable components. The unserviceable status of the component should be clearly declared on a tag together with the component identification data and any information that is useful to define actions that are necessary to be taken.
findings.reasoning: The MOE section discusses technical records, storage, and destruction of documents, but does not describe how unserviceable components are identified, tagged, segregated, or controlled. There is no procedure for tagging components as unserviceable with relevant information as described in GM1 M.A.501(a)(2).
findings.recommended_fix:
Add a subsection on unserviceable component control. For example:

"Unserviceable components
- Any component found or declared unserviceable shall be immediately identified and segregated from serviceable stock.
- An unserviceable tag shall be attached to the component, indicating at least: part number, serial number, aircraft/position (if applicable), reason for removal (defect, life limit, AD, etc.), date, and reference to the relevant work order.
- The tag shall be attached in a way that prevents unintentional separation.
- Unserviceable components shall be stored in a designated, clearly marked area to prevent inadvertent installation, pending repair, scrap, or other disposition in accordance with approved procedures."

findings.requirement_id: M.A.501(b) & AMC2 145.A.50(d)(2) – issuing EASA Form 1 for items in storage without Form 1
findings.requirement_excerpt: Any item in storage without an EASA Form 1 or equivalent cannot be installed ... unless an EASA Form 1 is issued for such item by an appropriately approved maintenance organisation in accordance with AMC2 145.A.50(d). ... An appropriately rated maintenance organisation approved under Part‑145 may issue an EASA Form 1 ... in accordance with procedures detailed in the exposition as approved by the competent authority.
findings.reasoning: The MOE section does not describe any procedure for issuing an EASA Form 1 for components in storage without an EASA Form 1 or equivalent (e.g. legacy parts, parts removed serviceable from aircraft, parts from withdrawn aircraft) as per AMC2 145.A.50(d). No steps are given for inspection, documentation review, or the specific wording in Form 1 blocks 11 and 12.

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.50 – responsibility and scope of CRS vs continuing airworthiness management
findings.requirement_excerpt: A certificate of release to service issued by a maintenance organisation certifies that the performed maintenance work, as agreed in the work order or the contract, has been completed in accordance with the applicable requirements and the maintenance organisation’s approved procedures. In the case of aircraft maintenance, it does not necessarily mean that the aircraft is in airworthy condition. Ensuring that the aircraft is airworthy before each flight always remains the responsibility of the person or organisation managing the aircraft continuing airworthiness.
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes the CRS as confirming that the aircraft/part is approved as airworthy "in these respects" and links it to the work order and maintenance requirements. However, it does not explicitly clarify that the CRS only certifies the maintenance performed and that overall airworthiness before each flight remains the responsibility of the continuing airworthiness management organisation/operator. This is more a clarification than a strict requirement, but including it would align the MOE with the guidance.
findings.recommended_fix:
Add a clarifying statement on the scope of the CRS. For example:

"The CRS issued by the maintenance organisation certifies that the maintenance work specified in the work order has been completed in accordance with applicable requirements and this MOE. It does not in itself guarantee the overall airworthiness of the aircraft. Ensuring that the aircraft is airworthy before each flight remains the responsibility of the operator/CAMO in charge of continuing airworthiness."

findings.requirement_id: Record‑keeping – retention of maintenance records (linked to Part‑145 general obligations)
findings.requirement_excerpt: Maintenance document files preserved at least three years thence from the date, when the aircraft or part thereof has been certified as airworthy and has left the maintenance organisation.
findings.reasoning: Although the exact Part‑145 record‑keeping paragraph is not included in the excerpts, the MOE states that maintenance documents are retained for at least three years from the date the aircraft or part has been certified and has left the organisation, that records are stored securely (locked metal cabinet or secure databases), and that the technical manager is responsible for proper storage and protection from damage, alteration and theft. This aligns with the typical Part‑145 requirement for minimum three‑year retention and secure storage.
